for this video LINCOLN, Maine — The term "pen pal" often conjures images of letters sent across time zones or continents. But sometimes, the most meaningful connections come from just a few towns away. AtLakeview Terrace Residential Carein Lincoln, a group of residents recently met their pen pals—students fromEast Grand Elementary School—for the first time. "This is me and this is my pen pal," 63-year-old resident Kathleen Smith said, pointing to a drawing on a letter. The two groups have been exchanging letters for months. What began as simple notes has grown into heartfelt friendships. "I started writing the best I could," Smith said. "These girls were sending me back pictures. It's like having these two as a sister." That bond was felt immediately when the students and residents finally came face-to-face. "Macy, this is Kathleen!" fourth-grade teacher Paula Chrone said as one of the pen pals was introduced. "Every time we write, we get to know each other more," Lakeview Terrace resident Christine Bernstein said. "Now we get to meet in person, and it's even better." The pairings had a chance to reflect on the stories they've shared about their lives through the stacks of paper they've sent to one another since last fall. "She always listens and writes amazing things back," student McKenzie Huff said while sharing a moment with her pen pal Kathleen. "They tell me how they’re doing at school, about their pets and whatnot," Bernstein added. Not only reminiscing, but creating new memories face-to-face. "We've been talking, listening to music, and eating lunch," Huff said. "He never got a picture of me—but now he knows what I look like," Bernstein laughed. Staff at Lakeview Terrace and teachers from East Grand say the exchange has become something special for everyone involved. "The residents love the young energy the children bring," Lakeview Terrace Director Ann York said. "You can see they just liven up—they talk." "Even though they're from different generations, they find so much they have in common," Chrone added. For Smith, it's little things like sharing a meal and some laughs with her pen pals Andi Faulkner and McKenzie Huff that remind her that friendships aren't limited by age. "I feel like I gained a lot of friends here," she said. "These girls will always be my pen pals." With plans to keep sending letters, both residents and student says they're excited to continue growing with one another. "I will write to you when I get a chance," she told them.
